questions.question: What is the molar volume of any ideal gas at Standard Temperature and Pressure (STP)?
questions.explanation: Avogadro's hypothesis states that one mole of any gas at STP occupies a volume of exactly 22.4 liters.

questions.question: What conditions define Standard Temperature and Pressure (STP)?
questions.explanation: STP is officially defined as 273.15 K (0°C) and a pressure of 1 atmosphere (101.3 kPa).

questions.question: How many moles are in 44.8 Liters of Helium gas at STP?
questions.explanation: Divide the volume by the molar volume: $44.8 \text{ L} / 22.4 \text{ L/mol} = 2.0 \text{ moles}$.

questions.question: What is the volume of 0.50 moles of $CO_{2}$ gas at STP?
questions.explanation: Multiply the moles by the molar volume: $0.50 \text{ mol} \times 22.4 \text{ L/mol} = 11.2 \text{ L}$.

questions.question: Avogadro's Hypothesis states that equal volumes of different gases at the same temperature and pressure contain equal numbers of:
questions.explanation: Regardless of the size of the gas molecules, the same number of particles will occupy the same volume under identical conditions.

questions.question: Which of the following gases would occupy 22.4 L at STP?
questions.explanation: Exactly one mole of any gas (like $O_{2}$) occupies the molar volume of 22.4 L at STP.

questions.question: To calculate the density of a gas at STP, you should divide the molar mass by:
questions.explanation: Density equals mass divided by volume. For one mole of gas at STP, $\text{Density} = \text{Molar Mass} / 22.4 \text{ L}$.

questions.question: What is the volume of $3.011 \times 10^{23}$ molecules of $N_{2}$ gas at STP?
questions.explanation: $3.011 \times 10^{23}$ molecules is 0.5 moles. $0.5 \text{ mol} \times 22.4 \text{ L/mol} = 11.2 \text{ L}$.

questions.question: If the temperature of a gas is increased above 0°C while pressure is constant, the volume of 1 mole of that gas will be:
questions.explanation: According to Charles's Law, volume and temperature are directly proportional; increasing temperature increases volume.
